en: Interview with Frances Fox Shambaugh, 2019-10-13

Interview with Frances Shambaugh, lifelong resident of Gatlinburg. Shambaugh recounts her evacuation and time spent afterwards at the community center. She discusses the efforts in the community to support one another and her own efforts at rebuilding her home and studio. This is a representative quote from the interview: "It brought people together and there was a strong sense of community. A strong sense of not only us helping each other, but people all over the country helping us."

Interview with Frances Fox Shambaugh, 2019-10-13
Interview Questions
Could you state your name and a little about how long you've been in Gatlinburg?
Can you tell us about what you've been doing in Gatlinburg since moving back?
Where were you when you first became aware of the fire in the park?
After getting to the community center, what were your thoughts?
When did you first learn about the fire reaching your house?
What was your feeling when you learned you had lost your house?
When you couldn't go back home, what did you do?
How long did you stay in the shelter?
What kind of activities were you doing during that time?
At what point did you get back to see your home?
What was your reaction seeing your home destroyed?
How long did you stay there that first day?
What was your thinking process at this point?
Did you talk with your neighbors about the loss?
Being in the rental house had a creepy feeling?
Did you ever get back into regular Arrowmont programming during this time?
Can you describe the sense of community that was at Arrowmont?
At what point did you start thinking about your business?
Did the community come together and share a studio?
After reestablishing your business, what did you do about your home?
Did you have any difficulties contacting friends and family during the fire?
At any point in the fire did you feel that you were in danger?
How did this event impact you emotionally?
How did this event impact you emotionally?
Have you managed to recover your business?
Have you made any provisions in case this happens again?
Did you build your house back similar?
How did the fire shape community relations?
Did anything surprising or good that came out of this?
What effect did the media coverage have?
Is there anything else that you would like to share?
Was the outpouring in the community what you expected?
